After design and fabricating this X configuration omni drivetrain the base drift undesirably in the northeast (diagonal) direction, can anyone know the cause of this problem and how to eliminate it or it is a common in such type of drivetrain and should be compensated for it in the code ?

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Could be weight distribution, wheel alignment, or wheel velocity variation.

The solution in most cases is to use a gyro to close the loop on heading control.

posts.name: SoftwareBug2.0
posts.cooked:
I think those are the most likely culprits.  However, also:

-Double check the math in the code -Did you use some ancient speed controllers that were gathering dust?  If so calibration of speed controllers may be in order. -How much ground clearance do you have?  From the picture it looks really close, so you might want to check you are not dragging on the floor -How close is the diameter of each of your wheels?  If you have uneven wear the same number of revolutions on different wheels will make you go different distances.

I don’t think this is related to the problem, but those extra wheels on the side are an interesting feature.

posts.name: Ibrahim Hassan Mohamed
posts.cooked: We will try this solution, thanks in advance

JamesCH95:

The solution in most cases is to use a gyro to close the loop on heading control.

Only if it’s not a tolerance issue. If a wheel (or more often, a pair of wheels) just isn’t making good (or any) contact with the ground, the system behaves as an underactutuated system and most feedback control methods do not work. The only way to make it drive somewhat predictably without fixing the mechanical issue is to make the robot constantly spin or translate while spinning.

FTC bots get away with sloppy tolerances because they are driven on foam mats, but idk this robot’s application so it might be driving on uneven concrete for all I know.

ibrahimhassan:

how to eliminate it or it is a common in such type of drivetrain and should be compensated for it in the code ?

Since this doesn’t look like an FRC bot, you can completely eliminate any mechanical issues by adding suspension. I can’t tell the size of the drivetrain, but some shocks with oil-based dampers should get the job done.

Building the frame to tighter tolerances, such as using a certified flat surface and clamps during assembly can also help, the issue with less effort, but may not be a permanent fix.

posts.name: SoftwareBug2.0
posts.cooked: I also have not used those specific speed controllers.  However, a quick look at the manual for them suggests to me that their response to throttle input is programmable.  If they happen to not all be programmed the same way this could cause unequal responses.  In particular, I would be especially suspicious of the parameters named “turbo timing”, “turbo delay” and “drag brake force.”

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Is the frame “flat”? If it is not, there will not be equal pressure on each of the 4 wheels and it will not behave as intended.

If you have 4 identical scales, you can measure the force applied to the floor by each wheel. If you have only one scale, it can still be done but you will have to make 3 blocks that are identical in height to the scale.
